awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Scalable Manufacturing Enabled by Highly Tunable Multiphase Liquid Metal Pastes with Solid and Fluid Capsule Additives
awd_abstract_narration:
Liquid metals such as gallium and its alloys have a variety of prospective applications such as in electronic devices, catalysis, energy harvesting and biomedical use but face challenges with manufacturing, tunability and cost that limit them from widespread use. This research project seeks to investigate how incorporating small-scale solid and/or fluid fillers into the liquid metal, i.e. liquid-metal pastes, have the potential to extend the range of physical and chemical properties and increase their economic appeal for additive manufacturing and other technologies. To overcome the challenges associated with the high cohesive energy density of liquid metals, the team proposes to use naturally formed nanometer-thin gallium-oxide shells as a wetting agent (or surfactant) for encapsulating foreign materials of different phases. The resultant liquid-metal pastes represent a novel class of materials with unexplored properties that can advance wearable electronics, soft robotics, and thermal management of electronics. The visual and hands-on nature of the proposed research will enable multiplatform community outreach including engaging K-12 tour groups with a hands-on activity using a video-game controller to operate a three-dimensional printer in making liquid-metal parts.

This research aims to realize a generalized way to encase gases, liquids, and solids inside liquid metals and to understand the role of the encasing native oxide in doing so, which creates a unique “surfactant” that forms in situ. These multiphase materials will be formed by mixing (or bubbling fluids) under controlled conditions and subsequently characterized thoroughly to establish process-structure-property relationships. The investigation will elucidate the mechanism by which this oxide “surfactant” works to create foams and pastes with trapped air pockets and liquids or solid objects, respectively. The oxide “enveloping” ability will enable a new class of conductive multiphase pastes with highly tunable density, rheology, as well as electrical and thermal conductivities. With the new fundamental insight, this project will also aim to create liquid-metal based materials that can be effectively three-dimensionally printed onto substrates with almost any composition and shape for two specific studies. The first one is to achieve a foam that is up to 10 times more cost-effective and lighter than pure liquid metals and yet fits for stretchable electronic devices. The second study is to create a paste that secretes small amounts of secondary liquid when applied and thereby improves thermo-mechanical contacts of next-generation thermal interface materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Liquid metals, such as gallium and its alloys, have various applications in electronic devices, thermal management, and biomedical fields. However, challenges such as manufacturing difficulties, limited tunability of properties, and gallium-induced corrosion of contacting metals hinder their widespread adoption. This project addressed these limitations by incorporating small-scale fillers—solids, gases, and liquids (silicone oil)—into liquid metals to create innovative liquid-metal-based pastes, foams, and emulsions. Previous studies established the ease of dispersing liquid metal droplets in other materials, but the reverse-encapsulating secondary phases within liquid metals-is challenging due to the metal's high cohesive energy density. This projected revealed the critical roles of the naturally forming nanometer-thin gallium-oxide shell and liquid metal viscosity in successfully integrating secondary materials. The findings led to new material design guidelines and demonstrated unique characteristics of liquid-metal composites expanding their utility in additive manufacturing and microelectronics cooling.

The intellectual merit of this project was the fundamental advancement of the understanding of mechanisms and properties that control whether solids, gases, and liquids are internalized into liquid metals and how the internalization changes the properties of the resulting composite. The gallium oxide was shown to form a partial shell around solid particles, leading to the wetting by the liquid metal, and a complete shell around air bubbles and silicone oil droplets. The shells grown around the fluid (gas or liquid) fillers provide a physical barrier to their coalescence and thereby prevent separation of the liquid metal and added phases. The ability to grow a complete shell around silicone oil droplets prior to contacting other droplets during mixing also likely underlines rheological control over the emulsion formation. In particular, it was demonstrated that increasing the viscosity of the liquid metal increases its capacity to intake more silicone oil and/or silicone oil of higher viscosity.

The broader impacts of this project were the development of design guidelines for liquid metal pastes, foams, and emulsions that relate their composition to thermophysical and electrical properties. These design guidelines can facilitate the use of the composites in additive manufacturing and as thermal interface materials. For example, to make liquid metal pastes with minimized air content that have enhanced thermal or electrical conductivity, conductive particles with diameters in micrometer range or higher should be mixed into liquid. In contrast, the liquid metal should be mixed with sub-micrometer particles to make foams with maximized air content and therefore decreased density. The nanoparticles were demonstrated to self-assemble on the liquid metal-air interfaces and therefore strengthening the oxide shell and preventing phase separation. In turn, the silicone oil-in-liquid metal emulsions were demonstrated to have a sub-micrometer thin oil film on their exterior that acted as a conformable barrier and prevented gallium from corroding contacting metal foils, resolving one of the main industrial drawbacks of gallium. At the same time, the emulsions have a high thermal conductivity, making them ideal for new generation of thermal interface materials. The project also provided interdisciplinary training and a collaborative two-university experience for five graduate students at ASU and two at NCSU in addition to several undergraduate researchers. The visual and hands-on nature of the work enables multiplatform community outreach such as liquid metal printing demonstrations for K-12 visitors to our laboratories.

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2025
Modified by: Konrad Rykaczewski
